summary: Teenagers in Mississippi do a shot-by-shot remake of Steven Spielberg's 1981 feature film.

reviews.content: A rare example of fandom to the 100% degree.  not good in a the filmmaking sense, but impressive that kids did this.
Better than the original!
I don't even know where to see it, so...
wonderful. what a gem. pure dedication.

"Raiders of the Lost Ark: The Adaptation" is truly one of those fan films that has to be seen to be believe. Its really remarkable on how these filmmakers were able to remake this movie for the course of seven years. I give highly praise for Eric Zala, Chris Strompolos, and Jayson Lamb for all their hard work and effort to get this movie made. Steven Spielberg is really pleased for this movie too. I love this fan film, and it is definitely a whole lot of fun! One more thing, this is one hundred times better than that stupid shot for shot remake of Gus Van Saint's "Psycho." That movie was a cash grab, but this fan film wasn't made for Hollywood, it was made for their love of one of the greatest adventure films ever made. Nuf Said!

An embodiment of pure love for the cinema.

...a multi-layered dessert...

If this is the only film on RT with 100%, it is rightly so. Film making is all about using the resources you have to create more than you really have. The pleasure of watching ROTLATA is in seeing and understanding how everything has been achieved even as you suspend your disbelief. Nothing is truly hidden. And this creates a multi-layered dessert of the most exquisite and charming kind. It has the immediacy of theatre yet remains a movie. I swear I had tears in my eyes as I read the end credits in admiration at the dedication of all concerned. It isn't just a movie, it's an experience. I felt the optimism of my own childhood in the afterglow of this wonderful picture.

a great fan film. filmed over the course of a dozen years in backyards and basements on marginal budgets and homemade props. it is a near shot for shot remake of Raiders. The young filmmakers show amazing endurance and ingenuity. must see!!
Brilliant. These 3 kids deserved to meet Spielberg. What a fan service for the best Indy film and my 3rd favourite film of all time
i love the advanture

Raiders of the Lost Ark: The Adaptation can probably best be described as the real life version of Son of Rambow. A loving tribute, and a shot for shot remake of Spielberg's classic, created by a group of friends over a period of seven years. The performances and technical aspects are amateurish and all over the place, but that doesn't stop the movie from being wildly entertaining! Watching how the kids tackle the challenges of recreating the spectacular stunts and effects from the original is great fun, and it's all wrapped in huge swathes of charm. Heartily recommended for any fan of Indy and the DIY-aspects of Son of Rambow and Be Kind, Rewind!

I have nothing but admiration for these kids. Amazing job. Shame this has never been released whatsoever apart from the odd viewing.
Glad they chose Raiders, the definitive and far superior entry in the series.

I saw this at a film festival...they blew up this BETA shot remake onto the big screen...........imagine pixels the size of your head.  So good.  The kid playing Indie..hahah hilarious.  The mind blowing stunts these 12 year olds were pulling make this definitely worth to watch.  They were setting buildings on fire and hanging off moving vehicles.
5 stars for persistance, dedication and all other words that describe the qualities, which makes a move come through! read the story http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0772251/

This movie was amazing and so much fun to watch.

2 boys from age 11 thru to their teens make a dialogue, action and stunt play by play of the original Raiders and it's wonderful and amazing! They were serious, so it's charming and makes you feel like a kid again!
As an experience, definitely a five star one, but as a movie, well...plus, it's a remake!

Hilarious from start to end. If it comes to your town get tickets early and don't miss it. Ingenious, inspiring and not a little bit terrifying. Especially when 14 year old kids start lighting themselves on fire, throwing each other off trucks and generally put themselves in all sorts of harms way.

If they come to your city to show it, GO, would you, GO.  It's utterly fantastic.  Word of warning, though: they had three showings here in Portland, & every one of 'em sold out.  Get your tickets early.
The audio was virtually nonexistent, but it didn't matter, because everyone knows the dialogue to Indian Jones. A very inspiring effort.
I was really impressed with this one. Yes it's filmed on beta max & VHS tapes in the 1980s, but it was incredibly true to the original, and the stuns were so well done. I laughed so much also.

I saw this when it came to Northwest Film Forum a few years ago. One of the actors - I think it was Chris, but I'm not sure - was there, telling us stories about mishaps as they were shooting and showing off the whip he'd just bought from the guy who made the whips for the original movie. :) Definitely go see it, if you get the chance.

If this film is playing anywhere near you, go there a few hours ahead of time, even if that means standing in line outside the theater in the freezing cold. I did and it was totally worth it.  It makes me sad that kids today don't have that kind of ludicrously dangerous freedom that made this movie the amazing work that it is.
the most inspiring wonderful movie i've ever seen.  if anyone has copy, i will do anything to get my hands on it.

friggin' hilarious.  it really is amazing to think about all the effort all of these guys put into it as kids. in a way, it was more exciting than seeing many blockbuster movies of the present day, since this film was all DIY and didn't rely on CGI and big studio budgets. and all the creativity and imagination, too!
Seeing kids set each other on fire is a lot funnier than you'd think it should be.

Just saw it, and I must say, WOW! It's truly inspiring to see what some kids could accomplish back in the 80s and see it done SO well! If it comes to your school or town, definitely go and see it! And if not... It could every well be on the DVD of the movie being made about them. Two thumbs up!
I cant say enough for this movie. It was... It was great.

I thought this was very inspiring. It is extremely low budget, and the sound is bad, but the fact that these kids stuck to it is amazing. I was very impressed with the truck scene. This remake has a certain charm that cannot be denied, and the powerful story still sucked me in. Carrying a dog around on their shoulders instead of the double agent  monkey? Genius!!

Saw this movie Friday night...pretty amazing what a few kids could put together..especially back in the 80's without all the fancy digital editing equipment they have now.  I loved the cameo by Snickers the dog.

I'll give these guys a lot of credit.  It was cheesy, funny and very creative all at once.  It was mind boggling to hear that it took nearly 7 years to film this and that the actors/actresses were still around to finish everything -- true friendship!!
If you haven't seen Indiana Jones (the Hollywood version), first seen this adaptation first and then was Harrison Ford do his thing; it should be that much more enjoyable.

Kudos to the REAL stunt scenes and SNICKERS (the so-called monkey).

Oh here is a recent interview with Chris Strompolos: http://www.theindyexperience.com/interviews/chris_strompolos_interview.php
You ever pee your pants in a movie theater?  Well, you will when you see this movie!

Find out where this is screening and make a roadtrip out of it.  You'll be glad you did.  I was!

What I found especially cool is how the dialogue and story still hold up, even from kids with a ridiculously modest budget.

Oh and the evil nazi puppy was pretty stinkin awesome too.

What these kids did is amazing. You need to find a copy of this and see it. With the exception of 2 scenes I noted while viewing this the recreate Raiders to a T. An awesome experience that should not be missed. It could inspire future generations of becoming filmmakers.

If you have never seen it. You must somehow find it and watch it. Quite possibly the funniest thing I have ever seen. The dedicated kids who made this film back in 1982 and over the course of years painstakingly recreated the Raiders of the Lost Ark shot by shot. The result? The greatest adaptation of a film to ANOTHER film I have ever seen.
it was quite funny but because they filmed it so long ago the camera and audio was awful. great acting and stunt jobs tho!
What's amazing is that these kids pulled this off. The video's grainy and the dialogue is muddy at times, but they captured the spirit of Spielberg's epic.
Wow!  I wish I did this at their age.

You've got to give these kids credit.  I first saw this at the Oxford Film Festival, and I was blown away by the skill and devotion these kids showed towards their subject.  It's probably hard to find, but if you can get your hands on it, see it at all costs.
